alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for loans provided to employees
overview: Tax and reporting rules for employers providing loans to employees
title: Expenses and benefits: loans provided to employees

table.body:
As an employer providing loans to your employees or their relatives, you have certain National Insurance and reporting obligations.

##What's included

There are different rules depending on whether you provide:

* 'beneficial loans', which are interest-free, or at a rate below [HMRC's official interest rate](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/rates/interest-beneficial.htm "HMRC's official interest rate"){:rel="external"}
* loans you write off

###Beneficial loans

The rules cover beneficial loans advanced, arranged, facilitated, guaranteed or taken over from someone else by:

* you (the employer)
* a company or partnership you control
* a company or partnership that controls your business
* a person with a material interest in your business

See the [technical guidance](/expenses-and-benefits-loans-provided-to-employees/technical-guidance "technical guidance") for what to do in more complicated situations, eg if you use third-party arrangements to make a loan to your employee.

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You might not have to report anything to HMRC or pay tax and National Insurance on [beneficial loans](/expenses-and-benefits-loans-provided-to-employees/overview "beneficial loans").

A beneficial loan is exempt if you:

* provide it in the normal course of a domestic or family relationship as an individual (not as a company you control, even if you are the sole owner and employee)
* provide loans with a combined outstanding value to an employee of less than £5,000 throughout the whole tax year
* provide it to an employee for a fixed and invariable period, and at a fixed and invariable rate that was equal to or higher than [HMRC's official interest rate](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/rates/interest-beneficial.htm "HMRC's official interest rate"){:rel="external"} when the loan was taken out
* provide it under identical terms and conditions to the general public as well (this mostly applies to commercial lenders)
* provide 'qualifying loans' for which all of the interest qualifies for tax relief -- see the [technical guidance](/expenses-and-benefits-loans-provided-to-employees/technical-guidance "technical guidance") for an explanation of this complex area
* provide it to employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 per year (if they aren't directors)

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: What's exempt

table.body:
If the loans you provide [aren’t exempt](/expenses-and-benefits-loans-provided-to-employees "aren't exempt"), you have to report the costs to HMRC, and deduct or pay National Insurance on them.

##Beneficial loans

If you or your business provides a beneficial loan, as defined in the [overview](/expenses-and-benefits-loans-provided-to-employees/overview "overview"), you'll need to:

* report on form P11D, section H
* pay Class 1A National Insurance on the [value of the benefit](/expenses-and-benefits-loans-provided-to-employees/work-out-the-value "value of the benefit")

##Loans you write off

You always have to report and pay on loans to employees that you write off, whether or not they are classed as beneficial loans.

Who gets the benefit | What to do | What to deduct or pay
-|-|-
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 | Fill in form P9D, section A(2) | Deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) on the [value of the benefit](/expenses-and-benefits-loans-provided-to-employees/work-out-the-value "value of the benefit")
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more | Fill in form P11D, section M | Deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) on the [value of the benefit](/expenses-and-benefits-loans-provided-to-employees/work-out-the-value "value of the benefit")
Directors | Fill in form P11D, section M | Deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) on the [value of the benefit](/expenses-and-benefits-loans-provided-to-employees/work-out-the-value "value of the benefit")

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
*[PAYE]:Pay As You Earn
table.title: What to report and pay

table.body:
You can work out the value of loans using HMRC’s online tools through the [PAYE Online for employers](https://online.hmrc.gov.uk/paye/ "PAYE Online for employers") service, or commercial payroll software.

You can also work out the value manually on [P11D working sheet 4.](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kb5/hmrc/forms/view.page?record=YaOK4d6Yb1Q&formid=1156 "P11D working sheet 4"){:rel="external"}

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
*[PAYE]:Pay As You Earn
